channel.title: Mesostigmata on Plant Pests of the Middle East
channel.author: Uri Gerson

item.title: Amblyseius swirskii
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Amblyseius swirskii Athias-Henriot

Taxonomic placing: Acari, Mesostigmata, Phytoseiidae.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: Middle East.

Host plants: Many indigenous and introduced plants.

Morphology: Dorsum about 0.3-0.4 mm in length, almost smooth, with a few reticulations, and 17 pairs of nude setae plus two pairs of lateral setae. The sternal plate bears three pairs of setae, and there are three pairs of preanal setae.

Economic importance: Amblyseius swirskii is the dominant summer phytoseiid predator in citrus groves along the coastal plain of Israel, where it is possibly one of the main natural enemies of the citrus rust mite, Phyllocoptruta oleivora (Ashmead). More recently _A. swirskii _has been developed by the Dutch company Koppert B.V. as a natural enemy of thrips (Thysanoptera), and whiteflies (Aleyrodidae). By late 2006 more than one billion predators, mostly within slow-release bags, known as Swirski-Mite Plus, have been sold.

Life history:The female mite required less than one week to complete a generation at 27°C, produced 44 eggs when feeding on an eriophyid mite and lived about four weeks. The predator also feeds on other prey, including many pest mites, thrips, whiteflies, the eggs of moths (Lepidoptera) and the crawlers of scale insects (Coccoidea), as well as on pollen. Amblyseius swirskii has no winter diapause.

REFERENCES

El-Laithy, A.Y.M. 1998. Laboratory studies on growth parameters of three predatory mites associated with eriophyid mites in olive nurseries. Zeitschrift für Planzenkrankheiten und Pflanzenschutz 105: 78-83.

Porath, A. and Swirski, E. 1965. A survey of phytoseiid mites (Acarina: Phytoseiidae) on citrus, with a description of one new species. Israel Journal of Agricultural Research 15: 87-100.

Ragusa, S. and Swirski, E. 1977. Feeding habits, post-embryonic and adult survival, mating, virility and fecundity of the predacious mite Amblyseius swirskii (Acarina: Phytoseiidae) on some coccids and mealybugs. Entomophaga 22: 383-92.

Swirski, E., Amitai, S. and Dorzia, N. 1967. Laboratory studies on the feeding, development and reproduction of the predaceous mites Amblyseius rubini Swirski & Amitai and Amblyseius swirskii Athias (Acarina: Phytoseiidae) on various kinds of food substances. Israel Journal of Agricultural Research 17: 101-19.

Websites:

http://www.whitefly.org/whiteflyforum/forum_posts.asp?TID=82

item.title: Typhlodromus athiasae
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Typhlodromus athiasae Porath & Swirski

Taxonomic placing: Acari , Mesostigmata, Phytoseiidae .

Geographical distribution: Middle East, Greece and Libya.

Host plants: Many indigenous and introduced, annual and perennial plants.

Morphology: Length of the reticulated dorsum about 0.3 mm, with 17 pairs of nude setae plus two pairs of lateral setae. All dorsal setae on the anterior part of the body subequal in length, the posterior setae longer. A single macroseta present on leg IV. The sternal plate with four pairs of setae, and there are four pairs of preanal setae.

Economic importance: In Israel Typhlodromus athiasae is the dominant phytoseiid predator of the European red mite, Panonychus ulmi Koch on apples , and often reduces its populations. It is also the dominant phytoseiid on citrus trees in the inner parts of Israel and in the Nile Delta region of Egypt.

Life history: Typhlodromus athiasae raised a generation in 11-12 days at 25°C and produced about 30 eggs in 20 days at that temperature and 70% relative humidity. Fecundity was reduced at higher or lower relative humidities. The pollen of Carpobrotus edulis (Aizoaceae) and the spider mite Tetranychus urticae Koch provided the best nutrients for reproduction, but the mite can also survive and lay eggs on many other foods. A single mating sufficed for fertilizing all female eggs. The larvae did not feed but other stages were cannibalistic. The mite does not have a winter diapause.

REFERENCES

McMurtry, J.A. 1977. Some predaceous mites (Phytoseiidae) on citrus in the Mediterranean region. Entomophaga: 22: 19-30.

Rasmy, A.H., Zaher, M.A. and Albagoury, M.E. 1972. Mites associated with citrus in the Nile Delta (U.A.R.). Zeitschrift fur Angewandte Entomologie 70: 183-186.

Reuveny, H., Palevsky, E. and Gerson, U. 1996. Laboratory life history of the predaceous mite Typhlodromus athiasae. Systematic and Applied Acarology !: 45-54.

Swirski, E., Amitai, S. and Dorzia, N. 1967. Laboratory studies on the feeding, development and oviposition of the predaceous mite Typhlodromus athiasae P. & R. (Acarina: Phytoseiidae) on various kinds of food substances. Israel Journal of Agricultural Research 17: 213-218.

Porath, A. & Swirski, E. 1965. A survey of phytoseiid mites (Acarina: Phytoseiidae) on citrus, with a description of one new species. Israel Journal of Agricultural Research 15: 87-100.
